categorySummaries.summary: Netflix login is a two-step process: email entry on the first page, then password on the second. Google reCAPTCHA is present on the login page, which complicates automation. After login, users land on the 'Who's watching?' profile picker showing all 5 profiles with Kids badges visible.
keyTakeaways: Two-step login: email first, then password on next page
Google reCAPTCHA present — bot detection is active
Profile picker appears after login with all 5 profiles
Session cookies (NetflixId, SecureNetflixId) extracted post-login last ~2 weeks
No OAuth or delegated auth — credential-based login is the only option
categorySummaries.comparisonSummary: Similar to Peacock's credential-based login, but Netflix has stronger bot detection (reCAPTCHA). Neither platform offers OAuth for third-party parental control tools.

categorySummaries.summary: Netflix supports up to 5 profiles per account. Three types observed: standard adult profiles (Ramsay!, Mom and dad), and Kids profiles (Samson, Chap, BANANA!!!!!!!!). Kids profiles show a red 'kids' badge on avatars and provide a completely different browsing UI. Profile editing includes name, avatar, language, maturity level, autoplay settings, and Kids toggle.
keyTakeaways: Max 5 profiles per account — must check available slots before creating
Kids profiles have distinct red badge and restricted browsing UI
Profile edit pages accessible via Manage Profiles flow
Each profile has independent settings for maturity, autoplay, language
Profile Lock (PIN) is a separate setting per profile
Kids toggle visible on profile edit — converts between standard and kids mode
categorySummaries.comparisonSummary: Netflix offers 5 profiles vs Peacock's 6. Netflix's Kids profiles provide a fully separate UI experience, while Peacock's kids profiles are more limited in UI differentiation.

categorySummaries.summary: Parental controls are accessible per-profile under 'Manage profile and preferences'. Key settings include maturity rating level (4 tiers), title-specific restrictions, and profile lock PIN. All write operations to parental controls require MFA verification (email code, SMS code, or password confirmation). The MFA gate is the primary security barrier for automation.
keyTakeaways: 4 maturity tiers: Little Kids, Older Kids, Teens, All Maturity Ratings
Per-title blocking available under Viewing Restrictions
All parental control changes require MFA verification
MFA offers 3 methods: email code, SMS text, or password confirmation
Kids profiles have fewer visible settings (no Notification settings, no Privacy settings)
Parental controls accessed via Account > Profile & Parental Controls > [Profile]
categorySummaries.comparisonSummary: Netflix's MFA gate on parental controls is stronger than Peacock's approach. Netflix has 4 maturity tiers vs Peacock's simpler kids/non-kids model. Both lack native screen time controls.

categorySummaries.summary: Netflix requires multi-factor authentication before allowing any parental control changes. The MFA page presents three options: email a code, text a code (SMS), or confirm password. This gate activates when navigating to parental control settings, maturity settings, or profile management from certain paths. Password confirmation is the simplest path for automation.
keyTakeaways: MFA triggered on parental control write operations
Three verification methods: email code, SMS code, password re-entry
Password confirmation is the most automatable MFA path
MFA is session-based — once verified, changes can be made within that session
Direct URL navigation to parental controls also triggers MFA
Profile picker modal appears during MFA flow for profile selection
categorySummaries.comparisonSummary: Netflix's MFA is more robust than most streaming platforms. Peacock does not require MFA for parental control changes, making Netflix significantly harder to automate for write operations.

categorySummaries.summary: Netflix provides per-profile viewing activity showing title name, date watched, and episode/season info in chronological order. Data can be downloaded as CSV. Individual titles can be hidden from history. No watch duration, real-time status, or weekly summaries are available. The Shakti API endpoint /api/shakti/*/viewingactivity can be used for programmatic reads.
keyTakeaways: Per-profile viewing history with title + date + episode info
CSV download available via 'Download all' link
Individual titles can be hidden (permanently removed from history)
No watch duration or session length data
Shakti API supports read-only access to viewing activity
Show More pagination for large histories
categorySummaries.comparisonSummary: Netflix viewing history is more detailed than Peacock's, with CSV export and per-episode tracking. Neither platform provides watch duration data, which limits Phosra's screen time monitoring accuracy.

categorySummaries.summary: Netflix offers per-profile PIN locks using a 4-digit numeric code. The Profile Lock page allows creating, changing, or removing a PIN. A note indicates account password is required when making changes. This feature is critical for Phosra's screen time enforcement strategy — locking/unlocking profiles by managing the PIN.
keyTakeaways: 4-digit numeric PIN per profile
Password re-entry required to create/change PIN (not full MFA)
PIN prevents unauthorized profile switching
Primary mechanism for Phosra's screen time enforcement
PIN can be set on any profile including Kids profiles
Lock icon visible on profile picker for locked profiles
categorySummaries.comparisonSummary: Netflix's per-profile PIN is similar to Peacock's profile lock concept but Netflix's is more prominently featured and better integrated. Both use 4-digit PINs.

categorySummaries.summary: Netflix Kids profiles provide a completely separate browsing experience with simplified navigation, colorful design, large thumbnails, character-based browsing, and content restricted to age-appropriate ratings (TV-PG PG and below for Older Kids profiles). The Kids UI has no access to account settings, search for mature content, or profile switching without exiting.
keyTakeaways: Completely different UI from standard Netflix browsing
Character-based navigation rows for kid-friendly browsing
Content limited to profile's maturity tier (e.g., TV-PG PG and below)
No access to account settings or mature content search
Continue Watching row shows per-profile viewing progress
Top 10 Kids Movies/Shows featured prominently
categorySummaries.comparisonSummary: Netflix's Kids experience is significantly more polished than Peacock's, with dedicated character browsing, curated rows, and a fully distinct UI. This is an industry-leading kids content experience.

categorySummaries.summary: Netflix account settings are organized into 5 sections via left sidebar: Overview, Membership, Security, Devices, and Profiles. The Overview page shows membership status, payment info, and quick links to key settings including 'Adjust parental controls'. Security shows email, phone, password, and privacy options. Devices shows signed-in devices and download device management.
keyTakeaways: 5-section account layout: Overview, Membership, Security, Devices, Profiles
Quick link to 'Adjust parental controls' on Overview page
Security page shows verified email and phone number
Profile Transfer feature available (new) — Kids profiles cannot be transferred
Device management shows 4 of 6 download devices in use
Manage Profiles accessible from Overview and profile picker
categorySummaries.comparisonSummary: Netflix's account settings are more comprehensive than Peacock's, with dedicated sections for security and device management. Both platforms centralize parental controls under account settings.

categorySummaries.summary: Per-profile playback settings include autoplay next episode toggle, autoplay previews toggle, and data usage per screen (Auto/Low/Medium/High). These settings apply across all devices. Disabling autoplay is a key Phosra strategy to reduce passive binge-watching for children.
keyTakeaways: Autoplay next episode toggle (per-profile, cross-device)
Autoplay previews toggle (per-profile, cross-device)
Data usage settings: Auto, Low (0.3GB/hr), Medium (0.7GB/hr), High (3-7GB/hr)
Disabling autoplay reduces passive viewing — key Phosra strategy
No screen time controls in playback settings
categorySummaries.comparisonSummary: Netflix's autoplay controls are more granular than Peacock's. The autoplay disable strategy is unique to Netflix as a passive screen time reduction measure.

categorySummaries.summary: Per-profile privacy settings include Profile Lock, Viewing Activity access, and Data Privacy controls. The 'Matched Identifier Communications' toggle controls whether Netflix uses contact info for third-party marketing. An 'Opt Out of All' button is available. These settings are relevant for COPPA and child data protection compliance.
keyTakeaways: Profile Lock and Viewing Activity accessible from privacy page
Matched Identifier Communications toggle for marketing opt-out
Opt Out of All button for bulk privacy preference
Relevant for COPPA compliance on child profiles
Per-profile privacy settings, not account-wide
categorySummaries.comparisonSummary: Netflix's privacy controls are more transparent than Peacock's, with explicit opt-out options. Both platforms handle child privacy at the profile level.

categorySummaries.summary: Deep-dive screenshots capture per-profile settings pages for all 5 profiles (Ramsay!, MomAndDad, Samson, Chap, BANANA!!!). Each profile's settings, parental controls, playback, privacy, profile lock, and viewing activity pages were captured. Kids profiles (Samson, Chap, BANANA!!!) show fewer settings options — no Notification settings or Privacy and data settings sections. All profiles show consistent 'Manage profile and preferences' layout.
keyTakeaways: All 5 profiles have consistent settings structure
Kids profiles have reduced settings (no notifications, no full privacy section)
Parental controls expandable section shows maturity tier per profile
Each profile's viewing activity is independently accessible
Profile-specific playback settings (autoplay toggles)
Delete Profile option visible on non-primary profiles
categorySummaries.comparisonSummary: Netflix's per-profile settings granularity exceeds Peacock's. The deep-dive reveals that Kids profiles intentionally restrict available settings, which is a security-positive design.

01-login-page.png.description: Netflix login page showing 'Enter your info to sign in' heading with email/mobile input field, red Continue button, Get Help link, and Google reCAPTCHA notice at bottom. Dark background with Netflix logo.
01-login-page.png.phosraRelevance: Entry point for Phosra's authenticate() method. The two-step login flow (email first, then password) must be handled by Playwright automation. reCAPTCHA presence is a critical bot detection challenge.

automation.method: Playwright browser automation with stealth mode
automation.notes: reCAPTCHA on login page requires stealth mode to avoid detection. Two-step flow means separate page loads for email and password entry.
automation.technicalDetails: Navigate to netflix.com/login, fill email input[name='userLoginId'], click Continue, wait for password page. Use playwright-extra stealth plugin to bypass reCAPTCHA.

findings.label: reCAPTCHA present
findings.detail: Google reCAPTCHA is active on the login page — 'This page is protected by Google reCAPTCHA to ensure you're not a bot'

findings.label: Two-step login
findings.detail: Email and password are on separate pages, requiring two form submissions

findings.label: No OAuth
findings.detail: No social login or third-party auth options visible — credential-based login only

ux.notes: Minimal, clean login UI with clear input field and prominent Continue button. Dark theme consistent with Netflix branding.

securityNotes: Google reCAPTCHA bot detection active
No CAPTCHA image challenge observed but may trigger on suspicious activity
apiIndicators: No OAuth endpoint available — session cookie extraction is only auth method
01-login-page.png.comparisonNotes: Similar to Peacock's credential login but with stronger reCAPTCHA protection. Neither offers OAuth for third-party tools.
gapsIdentified: No OAuth or delegated auth pathway
reCAPTCHA may block automated login attempts

02-login-filled.png.description: Netflix login page with email field filled in (jake.k.klinvex@gmail.com). Same layout as 01 but with populated email input ready to click Continue.
02-login-filled.png.phosraRelevance: Demonstrates the email entry step of the authenticate() flow. Playwright fills the email field and clicks Continue to proceed to password step.

automation.notes: Straightforward form fill. Email input accepts email or mobile number format.

findings.label: Email format accepted
findings.detail: Standard email address format works in the input field

findings.label: Continue button enabled

securityNotes: Email address visible in plaintext in input field
apiIndicators: Form POST to Netflix login endpoint after Continue click
02-login-filled.png.comparisonNotes: Standard credential input step. Both Netflix and Peacock require email-first login flows.

03-after-login.png.description: Post-login state showing the Netflix interface after successful authentication. This confirms the login flow completed successfully.
03-after-login.png.phosraRelevance: Validates that authenticate() completed. Session cookies are now available for extraction (NetflixId, SecureNetflixId).

automation.notes: After successful login, extract session cookies for API reuse. Cookies last ~2 weeks.
automation.technicalDetails: const cookies = await context.cookies(); const netflixId = cookies.find(c => c.name === 'NetflixId');

findings.label: Login successful
findings.detail: Post-login page confirms authentication completed without MFA challenge

findings.label: Session established
findings.detail: Session cookies now available for Falcor/Shakti API calls

ux.notes: Smooth transition from login to authenticated state.

securityNotes: Session cookies set with ~2 week TTL
apiIndicators: NetflixId and SecureNetflixId cookies available for API calls
03-after-login.png.comparisonNotes: Both Netflix and Peacock establish session cookies post-login for API access.

04-profile-picker.png.description: Netflix 'Who's watching?' profile picker showing 5 profiles: Ramsay! (dinosaur avatar), Mom and dad (green smiley, lock icon), Samson (crab, kids badge), Chap (shark, kids badge), BANANA!!!!!!!! (golden retriever, kids badge). 'Manage Profiles' button at bottom.
04-profile-picker.png.phosraRelevance: Critical for listProfiles() and profile-to-child mapping. Shows all 5 profiles with visual indicators: Kids badges (red 'kids' label) on child profiles and lock icon on PIN-protected profiles. Phosra must map each child to their Netflix profile.

automation.notes: Profile data readable via Falcor pathEvaluator. Profile GUIDs extracted for subsequent API calls. Lock icon indicates PIN-protected profile.
